parts: guide me through installing git and git bash in powershell

Here’s the cleanest way to install **Git** (and **Git Bash**) on Windows using **PowerShell**, plus a quick verification checklist.

## 1) Check if Git is already installed
Open **PowerShell** (normal user is fine) and run:

```powershell
git --version
```

- If you see a version (e.g., `git version 2.x.y`), you’re done.
- If PowerShell says it can’t find `git`, continue.

## 2) Install Git (recommended: WinGet)
### A) If you have WinGet (most Windows 10/11 do)
Run:

```powershell
winget --version
```

If that works, install Git:

```powershell
winget install --id Git.Git -e --source winget
```

This installs **Git for Windows**, which includes **Git Bash**.

### B) If WinGet is not available
You can install via Chocolatey (if you already use it):

```powershell
choco install git -y
```

If you don’t have Chocolatey and want to keep everything simple, WinGet is usually the easiest. Otherwise you can install from the official installer UI (not PowerShell-only).

## 3) Make sure PowerShell can see Git (PATH refresh)
Close and reopen PowerShell, then run:

```powershell
git --version
where.exe git
```

If `git --version` still fails, it’s almost always one of:
- you didn’t reopen the terminal after install, or
- PATH didn’t update correctly.

## 4) Confirm Git Bash is installed and launch it
Git Bash is typically installed at:

- `C:\Program Files\Git\git-bash.exe`

Try launching from PowerShell:

```powershell
& "C:\Program Files\Git\git-bash.exe"
```

Or search **“Git Bash”** in the Start Menu.

If that file path doesn’t exist, locate it:

```powershell
Get-ChildItem "C:\Program Files\Git" -Recurse -Filter git-bash.exe -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
```

## 5) Basic Git setup (recommended)
Set your identity (used for commits):

```powershell
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "you@example.com"
```

Set a sensible default branch name:

```powershell
git config --global init.defaultBranch main
```

(Optional) Use VS Code as default editor if you have it:

```powershell
git config --global core.editor "code --wait"
```

## 6) Quick functional test
```powershell
mkdir git-test
cd git-test
git init
"hello" | Out-File hello.txt -Encoding utf8
git add .
git commit -m "first commit"
git log --oneline
```

If you see a commit in `git log`, you’re fully set.

---

If you run into an error at any step, paste the exact PowerShell output and I’ll tell you the minimal fix.
